title: Printrbot Play Shield with with view for filament.

description.text:
This is to help to prevent jamming while trying to figure out the best settings for flexibles on the Alu V2. It prevents jamming by allowing you to view the filament while you are tuning your print settings, pausing or quitting the print before it jams severely allowing you to recover and immediately resume printing after adjusting your settings (generally just slowing it down). Otherwise you may need to take off the shield and fix, then reattach the shield, which is just a waste of time.

I might add a fan nozzle in the future, but wanted to get flexibles working first. This version (compared to pictured version) has a bit more support to the bottom fan, as printing it the same way as the original printrbot design (as pictured) has no benefit.

The triangle is perfect for me, though some may want access to both allen bolts. It should be easy for people modify the design, but I've included the solidworks file as well.

description.text: For years I've had several vacuum tubes that I scavenged from my Grandfather's basement. However, they were pretty unsteady when trying to stand them up in a display case. The four shown here have three distinct base patterns - they probably have names but I don't know much more than they look cool.

The pictures show the result done in Black ABS. This was my first non-trivial ABS print and despite the large size I had a hard time getting it to stick to the base. When building, I needed to make sure the fan didn't come on for about 5mm (not 0.5mm as the original Cura settings had).

The holes in the base are designed to be exactly the same size as the tube pins. I wanted it to be a snug fit but when printed the plastic spreads a bit and make the holes too small. I drilled the holes out a bit to allow the pins to enter while still being snug.

description.text:
My former roommate and I went half and half on a Prusa i2 a year or two ago. After we decided we weren't living together again, we were faced with the question of who's going to keep the printer. I decided I wanted to create a larger printer, and long story short, this entire printer was created using that printer. Everything was designed by me. See the "Instructions" tab for a full build manual.

  • The total build volume is roughly 1 cubic foot (12" x 12" x 12").
  • The design challenges as well as a detailed overview of the printer can be found in the instructions.

NOTE - If you are building this printer, please make sure to check for updated files before printing the parts. I am constantly tweaking and redesigning this printer, and have been adding the revised files to each page, however the instructables link (below) will have a more in depth summary of each step regarding changes.**

The entire build as well as many details regarding hardware and components used can be found here: http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-Create-a-Large-3D-Printer-using-a-Smaller-3/

Thank you for your interest! As usual, any comments, critiques, and questions (within reason) are all welcomed!
-Pat

comments.text: fjsdc, Thank you, very cool! I talk about the reasoning more in the build provided in the "instructions" tab. To sum it up, the budget was the main factor which initially led me into the direction of printing all of the parts. Once I was convinced on my idea of printing extrusions, filling them with foam, and keeping the extrusions under constant compression, I decided to give it a shot and try something new.....To elaborate, the frame extrusions are filled with expanding foam (also with 15% PLA infill, to reduce PLA consumption). The extrusion sections are each 80mm tall (the height of my Prusa i2 used to print them), and glued together end to end, with 1/4" threaded rod running concentric through each of them and kept in compression. I have over 100 pictures and CAD drawings illustrating this in the "build manual".

comments.text: IndyRockStar76, Thanks! The heatbed is 12" x 12", so roughly an effective 11.5" x 11.5", by ~11.5" z height. As far as scaling the design, I see no reason why you couldn't scale it. Of course if you're looking to go any bigger, I'd recommend using aluminum extrusions as well as some good bracing.  The other main challenge to consider is the heated build platform. You'll find that there is a considerable cost jump even going from the standard ~7-8" square bed to something like a 12 x 12. Not only is the cost a jump, but more importantly, the current draw can be tough to work with. The original power supply I bought for this printer was a 475 W and it died within minutes. An alternative option that came to mind when designing this one would be to construct a "grid" of multiple heated beds to accomplish the same task.

title: 40x40x20mm Blower Fan Shroud for Rostock Max V2

description.text:
I couldn't find a shroud for a 40x40x20 blower fan so I modified the standard shroud with the STL provided by SeeMeCNC. I designed for a slight interference fit between the fan and shroud so light sanding may be required.

Hello!

This is a simple belt tensioner for the classic Rostock 3D Printer and its derivatives like the Rostock Mini.
It was simply derived by removing some mass from the stock idler end STL (credit to Johann Rocholl for the design!), so you can easily "slot-on" it to the rods. Great for removing belt slack.

Additional items:
M8 x 50mm Hex Bolt: 1
M8 Hex nut: 1
608zz bearings: 2

You can take it a step further by using the flanged F608ZZ to contain the belt and a nyloc nut, but so far the standard parts have worked.

As part of making a humidity sealed system to store my loaded filament in, I created a modified back tube guide for the Flash Forge Pro/Dual and other similar printers. I made it so you can use Push-In to fit connectors both directions as i'm using PTFE all the way to my sealed filament storage box.

CTC Creator Dual
WanHao Duplicator 3 & 4
FlashForge Creator I,II,III & X
MakerBot Replicator 1

This will require:

4x M6 Pneumatic Push-In Connectors for 4mm tubes
1x M6 thread cutter

*Only 2 push-in connectors need if you are only going to use PTFE tubing from this part to the extruders.

Dan Gelbart is an amazing engineer, designer, and entrepreneur.

In the included screenshot you can see a photo of the linear-positioning stage he created, which I've attempted to reproduce here with some minor modifications.

This is designed to be a demo object and would need to be modified to take into account material selection.

I don't recommend 3D printing this in plastic. Most hobbyist 3D printers will be unable to print the thin .010" walls needed to build the thin-sections which makeup the flexures that make the device work so well. Actually those walls are probably thinner than they need to be, so it may be possible to make this is plastic after all.

Ideally this design would be cut on a CNC waterjet cutter out of a single block of metal.

The major modification I've made to Gelbart's design is to expand the size of the stage mounting holes for 1" square optical mounts, giving you a 3x3 mounting pattern, and the 4 in-pattern mounting holes around them. Most optical components will slot into a design like this easily, using 1/4"-20 mounting holes.

Also, Gelbart's device features a 1:15 lever ratio, whereas this design features a 1:24 ratio.

But again, this is an untested, unvalidated copy for demo purposes only. I have no idea how well it would ultimately work.

Included also is a model and print for a precision-screw from McMaster-Carr designed to be used with the device to actuate it. The brass sleeve will fit in the bottom hole near the lever and provide the actuation force. I suppose you could put a spring behind this same bottom lever to provide opposite force. There is enough clearance to insert the brass sleeve on the inside of the bottom hole.

At the top of the device is another 1/4" hole for a precision measuring-device to measure stage movement.

Ideally, this design should produce a stage that can actuate in millionths of an inch with no backlash or hysteresis.

And if you want the source of the screenshot, it's from Gelbart's amazing 2012 videos on prototyping called "Making Prototypes" which can be found here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xMP_AfiNlX4

description.text:
A NEW VERSION OF THE DESIGN IS AVAILABLE
Check it out here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2751908
The new design is much better, looks gorgeous and needs no glue or screws.

This is a 3d-printed enclosure for the uranium project.
You will also need the complete uranium kit
https://hackerspaceshop.com/collections/art-and-beauty/products/uranium

A beautiful shiny necklace composed of:

  • An antique uranium glass marble
  • Some fancy microelectronics

Till the late fifties of the past century people made uranium glass things.
Thats glass with 2-3% radioactive uranium238 in it.
No kidding.

Uranium has the property of releasing beautiful yellow/greenish photons when its hit by UV light (google:fluorescence).

Half a century later overflo realised that UV light makes a very nice and distinct green glow inside uranium glassware and the uranium project was born.

What makes it special?

It is radio active!
A little.. very little actually.
In fact there is way more radiation hitting you if you board a plane or go hiking on a mountain.
But still.. it looks great.

SAFETY:

Q: Is it dangerous?
A: No. It's beautiful.

Q: But is it safe?
A: You are on a rock that rotates at 1670 km/h floating trough space. You are not safe. ever.

Q: But is this radioactive necklace thing safe?
A: You should not eat it.
Wearing it around your neck probably won't give you cancer.
On the other hand I am not a doctor and I don't want you to sue me.

Q: Are you kidding me? Is it safe now or what?
A: I measured the radiation with a geiger counter and the emitted radiation from the uranium marbles is SLIGHTLY above average background radiation that you experience all the time.
So no.. the emitted radiation is not harmful. Also uranium is a primary alpha radiator. Its radiation can be blocked by a piece of paper. As long as you don't get it inside your body you can feel pretty safe handling this material. It is also not raw uranium but uranium GLASS. That makes all the difference as the uranium is embedded in shielding material.

Printer:

the machine with the BING!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.05-0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Assembly

Fix the marble using super glue.
Insert the foam rummer inlay.
Insert the PCB from the back.
Add something to hand it around your neck, a leather band will work just fine.

Shine on!
Soap dish
Just another catapult with trigger and gunsight. Good to use from hand and table...

Printed with PLA, 20% fill density and 2 layers shell, but I think that with ABS it will be more fun and elastic...
And if you have printed it, then be patient and before bending it, give it a chance to cool down - otherwise it loses its springiness.

title: OPEN KITE
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Why don't you check the video first here?
https://vimeo.com/134607551

Alexander Graham Bell invented tetrahedral kites while he was trying to make an airplane more than a hundred year ago. Recently two British artists translated Bell’s invention into a flying sculpture, Little Shining Man (Heather & Ivan Morrison, 2011). At first I was fascinated by the flying sculpture and tried to build my own kites according to the current instructions on the internet to build tetrahedral kites with drinking straws and tissue papers, but soon I realised that the current way is quite labor intensive process. So I tried to design components for easier kite building, and also I could figure out a way of making the structure collapsible, so that people can carry or store the structure more conveniently. I think I converted Heather & Ivan Morrison’s flying sculpture into a more accessible product and I also made the component data downloadable so that people can download, 3d print and build their own collapsible tetrahedral kites.

You can find building instructions here.
http://www.sehunoh.com/openkite.html

I hope you enjoy it!

title: Big letters logo Blender + Blender guy

description.text:
Hello,

This project is a test for making large letters like signs.
It is possible to make larger letters of course but the idea was to create a "big" Blender logo for a desktop, a table or a presentation stand. The letters are empty with thin walls for not using a lot of PLA.
Why do I choose the Blender logo ? Because I use it and that I find this software brilliantly cool.

To animate the logo I have created a little character that one can put on the Blender logo (or anywhere else!)

IMPORTANT: If you reduce the size of the letters be careful to the fine walls. You might have holes in the letters during printing!

Everything can be printed without a raft or support but the character requires a little gluing.

I hope you will enjoy it.
Thank you.

author: LITHINES

description.text:
This is a 3D scan of me done using an ESUN structured light scanner. (I’m not affiliated with them). It uses four towers with a total of eight projectors and 16 cameras. Each full scan takes about two seconds. Photos of the scanning process can be found here.

Included is the raw OBJ output as well as a watertight, printable STL file.

I firmly believe in Open Source and while this is not exactly a technical achievement it’s what I have to offer. You are welcome to use this scan for your own projects but kindly remember it is of a real person who will probably see the end result. Be nice.

Update 8/30/15: I've uploaded a much nicer version of the cleaned up scan provided by ESUN. This does not have the distorted face the older file has. It's labeled "best version". They also provided the texture file which is in the zip archive.

title: Box for drill bits and other tiny Dremel tools

description.text:
Most of my drill bits got broken not by drilling, but by laying around on my working desk though. So why not building a box where they can rest safely till I need them?

Included are the FreeCAD source files if you would like to modify it. The upper shell is made in two parts witch I glued together. So I was able to print clean parts without any support.
The inlay is 4mm thick to prevent the bits from axial moving. This is maybe the main reason for broken drills.
The hooks need some easy support down to the inner edge. The inner edge is the inlay rest.

Print the upper shell in two parts without support and glue them together.

Print the bottom part with support between the inner edge and the hook tips. The support created by Cura is easy to remove. Just allow support at the material.

title: Adaptador Perfil 3030 para soporte de bobina (T-slot adapter for spool holder)

description.text:
Este adaptador encaja en los perfiles de 30x30 tipo B y crea un hueco para poder apoyar una varilla de 8mm y de ese modo hacer un soporte de bobinas.
En mi caso, para que no se mueva, he puesto en el extremo una tuerca autoblocante que encaja en la pieza.

This adapter fits into the type B profiles 30x30 and make a hole to support a rod 8mm and so make a spool holder.
In my case, so it do not move, I put in the end, a self-locking nut that fits the part.

Para su uso da igual ABS o PLA mientras que no sea excesivamente rígido y se pueda partir al introducirlo. Si la impresora o el material a usar no están bien calibrados puede costar mucho introducirlo, pero queda fijo y estable.
Para ahorrar tiempo imprimir a 0.25 o más si se tiene una boquilla con salida superior a 0.4mm ya que no es necesario definición en la pieza.

To use no matter ABS or PLA while not excessively rigid and can be from the insertion. If the printer or the material to be used are not well calibrated insert can cost much but is fixed and stable.
To save time printing 0.25 or more if your nozzle have more than 0.4mm output since it is not necessary on the part definition.

author: 3dprintsolutions

description.text:
My daughter asked me if I could create a 3D printed plastic mouthpiece for her Baritone Horn, that wouldn't freeze to her lips while participating in marching band, outdoors in January. I modeled the dimensions carefully after her metal mouthpiece and they sound the nearly same in side by side tests. Actually, I would say that the printed part sounds less harsh.
She has demonstrated it for her Band-mates, and now they want them too.

I printed this in ABS with with a 0.25mm slice thickness and a 95% infill, triple wall thickness.  
It requires some smoothing on the inside of the large part of the bell to be comforatble to use. I just sanded it with 400 grit sand paper, but an acetone vapor bath might work better.  
The small end gets very thin, so a cooling fan is needed, or there will be some deformation.

author: jbs

description.text: Want to make your own book? Here's a parametric template for those magnet-shut books that are found everywhere these days. It's based on A5, but is fully parametric (the thumbnails show two books with completely different parameters). The SCAD file and paper size conversion tool: https://github.com/l0b0/metal-book/ Possible mods: Different closing mechanism, different materials, etching or otherwise decorating surfaces. I'd love to see more fancy books at Thingiverse!

First, tweak the material dimensions in the configuration if you want. The parts will resize based on that. For example, if you don't want to use a magnet strip to close it (or are planning to add it as an inlay), simply set magnet_thickness to zero. To make by hand:
  • Print the OpenSCAD rendering with the "ECHO" statements, so you have all the measurements for building it.
  • Cut out the three metal pieces and the magnet strip.
  • Bend into shape. This can be tricky if the material is resilient, so you may want to drill the bottom filing holes and attach a piece of metal the same thickness as the paper. If you align them correctly, you should be able to bend around it without too much effort.
  • Drill the remaining holes.
    • To print:
  • Explode the view (just set explode to true) to make it manifold before exporting.
    • Either way:
  • Attach hinges.
  • Attach the magnet strip or other fastener.
  • Perforate your paper with a hole punch
  • Insert bolts http://www.boltdepot.com/Sex-bolts-and-Mating-screws.aspx to keep the whole thing together.

title: FFDF_Fully Functional Dubrovnik Fountain
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
// STILL DOES NOT WORK - water is still not flowing through the tubes (relying only on atmosferic pressure / if you blow in the sink with the straw (considering that you coated the model with nail polish or something simmilar) you will get the water flowing). When it will be done, I will remove this column and replace it with appropriate one.

// HISTORY

This is a model of one of many Dubrovnik's fountains. This one is placed just outside the Dubrovnik walls, in front of city doors Pile and it is called Jewish fountain (also known as Košer fountain). It was build in 1420. and it was originally situated alongside the famous Little Onofri's fountain. In 19. century the fountain was relocated to today's site. Geolocation: 42.641828, 18.105818. It can be seen in Street View.

// MAKING

On a trip to Dubrovnik, just outside of old town of Dubrovnik I saw this fountain and quickly photographed it with my phone from all angles. When I got home I uploaded it in free 123D Catch software. After some stitching i got my model which was about 50% OK. I cleaned the model, trimmed the rest and tapered the scan. Then it was time to model the rest of it (it took a while). The parts that are modeled and the parts that are scanned are shown separately on picture in gallery as well as scanned, cleaned and finished model.

// BONUS (the principle of Heron's fountain)

I didn't want to just make a model printable and use it for decoration - so i decided to make it functional. Using the principles of physics (water and air pressure) I designed a fountain that runs like a Heron's fountain - without any artificial pumps (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heron%27s_fountain). Simple - the water pushes the air from the lower cabin to the upper one (full of water). Water from the upper cabin looks for the fastest and easiest way out which is the tube that runs from the lions mouth. That water fills the lower cabin. When the process stops, you can easily flip the fountain - let the water flow from the lower to the upper cabin, flip it again and start the process by adding the water to the lower cabin via the sink.

I have made many prototypes - the latest is shown in the gallery along with the problems I spotted shown on the picture. This prototype worked but only if i blew through the straw into the sink. I am hoping I solved all the problems and that the fountain will work. (currently I am printing the latest model). If however not - you still have a beautiful sculpture. :)

// TWO FILES

The first file (FFDF_Jewish fountain_Dubrovnik_scale10) is a scaled model of a real thing in scale 1:10. It can be used for decorations but it is not functional (water does not flow) - it is just a "picture" (3D model) of the real fountain.

The second file (FFDF_Jewish fountain_Dubrovnik_functional) is a 3D model of the fountain but with the water flowing. I didn't test it yet (except for my prototypes) because I didn't have time, but theoretically, it should work. If someone makes it before me, please let me know if it works!

//
At the end of the gallery there is a picture of a test print (lions head) - part of a model printed with semi-transparent PLA so you can't see it clearly but it printed out great for that size (54x48 mm)
//
Both models can be printed without support.
//
Also, considering that the city of Dubrovnik is currently a set for King's Landing - Lannisters! ;)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2

remixed_from.author: fwhardijzer
remixed_from.title: Fully parametric herringbone gears for Wade extruders

title: Ultimate Greg's Wade's Geared Extruder - 30mm version

description.text:
This is the classic Greg's Wade's Geared Extruder, revisited in August 2015, with complete OpenSCAD source code including the herringbone (a.k.a. fishbone) gears. It is configured by default for mounting on a Prusa i3 or P3Steel X-carriage with 30mm hole spacing (such as this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:586636 ), and for a J-Head or E3D extruder (original or cheap clone) with 16mm mount diameter.

There are two more remixes available for this extruder, one is the 24mm version for older Prusa i3 carriages, the other is a Bowden version.

The default source code and the included STL files are configured for 1.75mm filament, but this is just an option in the source code and it can be recompiled for 3mm filament.

Note that there is also a complete layer fan system that fits this extruder perfectly, it can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:540716 .

The OpenSCAD source code for the extruder itself is based on the latest code by Misan from March 2014, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:65939 , with a few small changes.

The OpenSCAD source code for the fishbone gears is a small remix of the excellent, newly rewritten source code by Frans-Willem Hardijzer from May 2015, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:818003 .

Printed here in PLA with 0.3mm nozzle, 0.2mm layer height, 50% infill for the body and 60% infill for the gears.

Note that the source code allows for adjusting various configuration options (e.g. gear ratio) and print tolerances, so I strongly recommend checking the OpenSCAD source code and generating your own STL files it for your particular setup.

BTW the included involute gears library by Greg Frost has been updated for the current stable version of OpenSCAD (dated March 2015) and will not compile with older versions.

comments.text: Just a quick warning for others - when I tried to print this in a 3mm config with 0.3mm layers, my Slic3r skipped a layer between the main extruder body (right after the motor mount completes) and the filament guide portion, resulting in layer separation and a crappy print (it might still work in a pinch, I'm printing this as a holdover/spare until I convert my old Prusa i3 to a 1.75mm MK2S clone...

title: Go Pro HD Hero Case / Mount

description.text:
I made this thing so i could mount my original Go Pro HD Hero onto my Bonsai flying wing. It's probably a little heavy with the HD Hero on a Bonsai (wing), but it does fly. It has been tested and is working well. I do not have a HD Hero 2 or Hero 3 to test with, but I'm assuming they are slightly smaller and will not fit this case.  
The picture of the mount on the wing is a previous version which didnt have the side hole for accessing the USB slot and other ports, as well as not having the lens protection. The downloadable .stl and .scad files do include this as show in the thingiview.  
This could be adapted to be mounted to any other type of wing or plane. I have included the .scad file for modification if needed.  
I'm also still learning to use OpenSCAD so the code isnt brilliant (or pretty). If you have any suggestions or ideas to make the case better i'd love to hear from you.

This was printed using the following settings: 0.2mm Layer Height
15% infill
2 Shells
100mm/s print speed
120mm/s travel speed Made using a Replicator 2 running Sailfish 7.4. Sliced with Skeinforge. I got excellent results using the above settings.

Never know how much spaghetti to cook when receiving guests? Always ending up short, or with leftover pasta? Fear no more, as you can now have your very own spaghetti servings measuring tool!

This tool allows you to measure from 1/2 to 6-1/2 servings, and is much easier to use than those existing measuring tools using holes as serving sizes. Simply fill the slots you need up to the top!

Supported pasta : Spaghetti, Spaghettini, Fusilli, Bigoli, Bavette, Maccheroncini, Bucatini, Vermicelli, Capellini, Linguine, Fettuccine, and more!

This model was made using FreeCAD, and is not parametric (yet). Right now I just created 4 different versions, depending on how much plastic you want to save. They should all do the job, but the large ones are probably easier to use.

Prints easily without any support (lay flat).

I recently made a choker-style necklace from some WS2811 addressable LED strand I had on hand which is 1cm wide. I designed and iterated on this clasp mechanism a couple of times before settling on this design. It uses a clipping mechanism inspired by the CLASP Simpler Watchband design After initially modelling and using a simple clasp-like connector, I found the choker would sometimes pop open if I tensed my neck, so I've added a little tooth which hooks in to one of the sewable holes in the male end. By sewing in the receiving female part with the tooth facing outwards, a tight fit will press the tooth in to it's other half and make the clasp attach more firmly, while still being easy to intentionally remove.

I printed this thing using a Makerbot Replicator 2 with Makerbot "Natural" clear PLA filament, using the Makerware software on the 'High' profile with shells set to 8 so it's shells all the way through - every part is totally solid, which looks super nice with the clear filament.

description.text: I recently made a simple LED choker from fabric covered WS2811 addressable LED strip. The lights each consist of very harsh tiny points of light, so I printed a little light pipe diffuser cap to put on the top of each little 5050-style RGB LED to diffuse the light and carry it though the fabric lining to the outside. "Style 4" in the OpenSCAD file is the style I ended up settling on as being the best. Style 1 worked well, but was difficult to print, often getting broken when trying to remove it from the build plate, while style 2 and style 3 were both print failures (partly overhangs too severe), while Style 4 is largely a refined more rugged version of style 1, with less overhang, so less to tidy up.

Printed on a Makerbot Replicator 2 with the included clear "natural" PLA filament, using makerware with the regular 'high' profile and shells set to > 20 to make the whole thing solid and out of concentric circles, without any grid-like infilling for nicer light distribution.

The Simple can benefit from having less moving mass. McMaster parts needed: 52335K32 Metric Extreme-Temperature Tubing Made with PTFE, 2 mm ID, 4 mm OD, 1 mm Wall, Semi-Clear White. $2.45 Per Foot (two or more feet required). 5449K171 Metric Black Acetal Push-to-Connection Tube Fitting, Adapter for 4MM Tube OD X 1/8" BSPT Male Pipe. $2.21 Each (two required). You should use a 5/8 end-mill or drill to clean the 16mm hole that the hot-end pushes into. Also use a 6-32 tap on the screw holes. Tap the plastic for the 1/8 inch pipe threads using either a tap or a metal fitting. You may have to use an "R" size drill bit before you tap. You may want to experiment with chamfering the inside edges of the tubing with a small drill or even a drill of about 2.5mm size / 0.095" to ream the ends of the tube to have less resistance. I recommend ordering at least four feet of tubing so that you can experiment. Note that the cold-end plate does not have the filament path in the center, so please pay attention to which way you install it. If you adjust your hobbed-filament drive too tight, it will flatten the filament and then it won't pass smoothly through the tubing. Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fODSciCqP74

Replacement landing gear for DYS 250 glass/carbon fiber quad.

I lost one of mine in a crash, and thought I'd make a quick replacement. v2 should hold on a little stronger. Depends on which material you print with. v1 may be OK for PLA.

I printed a set of 4 in ABS (green filament, pictured) and they hold on great, but I broke off the short end trying to remove. I don't think I followed my own advice about perimeters this time, but added fillets to those critical corners to help on v3.

Suggest 3 perimeters, 3-5 top/bottom layers, and ~50% infill.

To design this, I took a well-lit photo of the original, then imported and traced it in Sketchup. I then used a few key measurements to scale it properly.

Worked surprisingly well!

This is an advanced and very precise version of the Z Adjustment for Camiels Orca 0.4x printer. You can adjust your height with a micrometer screw, while the Z-opto is leaded by two linear bearings on two 8 mm smooth rods in its height. There are two springs which press against the micrometer screw and make sure that there is no play in your height. This will also prevent your micrometer screw from de-adjusting itself. Also i have added a version of the middle part with 8 mm inner diameter, in case you dont have linear bearings laying around. The diameter for the smooth rods and the micrometer screw are zero by zero in this stl files, but you can edit the IGES files by your needs. This project was inspired by Mooselakes Adjuster: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58897

This parts were printed in ABS with 25% infill and 0.25mm layer height. The build up should be self explaining, but feel free to ask your questions.
If you need to drill your parts, drill them together to get a good alignment for your smooth rods.
Also i would recommend to add washers between the springs and linear bearings as a protection. Parts you need:
M4x12 screw x5
M4 nuts x7
M3x12 screw x2
M3 nuts x2
D 8mm / L 40mm springs x2
8 mm linear bearings x2
8mm smooth rods L 90mm x2
and of course, a micrometer screw. mine is 0-25mm, but you can also use a 0-13mm version.

title: Printrbot simple 1405 GT2 belt bearing support

description.text:
This thing adds support to the GT2 belt bearings by mounting on top of the bearings via the NEMA17 holes and fitting tightly around the screw heads that hold the bearings in. This way the screws are supported on both ends.

I made this after I had my X bearings collapse under the pressure of the GT2 belt tension and cause the belt to slip off. This thing was designed based on the Y carriage and y ends here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:372467/#files

I am not sure if you need the above upgrade. It all depends on whether the support plate fits under the stock y carriage plywood, I didn't try (if you do post and let everyone know).

This should work with the X axis as well, but I didn't try on that either because I had already hand fabricated a similar device since my printer was not operable.

print with supports, make sure you place the flat side down. when it's done printing you should just need to clear the supports out of the screw holes then it mounts over the top of the NEMA17 holes for your motor. You will probably need slightly longer screws than you're currently using (it will add 3mm).

comments.text:
If anyone has tried this in the following scenarios can you post a comment letting me know if it did or did not work so I can update the description:

1) using the original wood printrbot parts

2) on the x axis.

I think it should work for both of the above but would like to make sure.

title: Filament dry box for 3-4 spools of filament

description.text:
My dry box for 3 - 4 spools of filament. There are many dry box plans out there. This one is mine.

The rod is at a good height for most spools when using a pair of spool hubs on each spool

1 Sterlite 20qt air tight box.
24 3mmx10mm machine screws (3mm x 8mm will work but I like a little bit of thread sticking out of my nylocks)
24 3mm nylock nuts
24 3mm washers
1ft 3mm OD x 2mm ID PTFE tube.
1 12in 5/16 threaded rod

I used 3mm OD x 2mm ID PTFE tube because its what I had on hand.
The nut reliefs are too shallow (1mm) on all parts, but they worked for me.
The round base of the rod holder and the U shaped 'extrusion' are perpendicular to each other. The Sterlite box has an angle of like 3 degrees or so on all sides. It's not a big deal.

Loaded several versions of the U shaped rod holder.
m3 with reliefs (m4 hole w/ m3 nut relief. This one also has an itty bitty section to center the rod. It makes it special.)
m3 with reliefs dry-ish edition (Same as above but with some added flavor. It makes it extra special. And I couldn't get it to print very well either. .2mm deep relief text on the back.)
8-32 with reliefs (m5 hole w/ 8-32 nut relief)
m5 hole with no reliefs

For a size reference, the red filament is Hatchbox PLA, the one in the middle is EasyFil PLA, and the one on the right is Makergeeks ABS.

I haven't had the rod holder pullout of the sterlite box walls using m3 washers, but if they do I'll post a backing plate.

There isn't much to it.

Source a Sterlite 20qt air tight box.
I got mine at Target for $7.

Source your hardware and threaded rod.
I got my threaded rod at Home Depot. Prices vary depending on material. $1.75 or so for Zinc or $6 for the blingy stainless. (Do people still say blingy?)

Cut four holes per side for your bolts to hold the U shaped rod holder. I went 3.75" down from the top of the molded in handle. That will get you down about half way. This number can vary but it's what I went with. Don't go down too much lower or your spools will touch the bottom of the box, but you can go a bit higher. Too high and the rod won't center nicely.

Attach your rod holders.
Place your threaded rod in the holders and push down. There should be a satisfying click when its seated. Ah...

You probably don't want to use my pass throughs. Seriously, who in the world has 3mm OD x 2mm ID PTFE tube? But if you do, I eyeballed the locations for these. They sit just below the radius at the top of the box. The PTFE tube is a tight fit. You may need to ream the hole out with a pin vise and appropriate bit. It is supposed to be a little snug so that the PTFE tube doesn't move around too much while at the same time not deforming or pinching the tube.

I'd suggest you use an alternative pass through that utlizes a pneumatic push fit connector for 4mm OD PTFE tubing. Way better, but as the description noted, I had 3mm OD PTFE tubing so I designed my way around the material on hand. That and I simply couldn't find a source for 3mm OD push fit connectors for a reasonable (Cheap!) amount of money.

In the images, the discerning eye may notice that I'm using nylock nuts to hold my hubs in place. Yeah don't do that. Use normal jam nuts or suffer in trying to thread a nylock onto a threaded rod. It's doable, but not worth the effort.

Don't wrench down on the nuts against the bearings either. Give it a hair of wiggle room so it can spin nice and smooth with a tiny bit of resistance. If there is play it may lead the spool to spin due to imbalances and lead to a tangled mess.

When adding spools to the rod, make sure that all of the filament comes off the spools in the same orientation.

As for the debate of if you need a dry box or not, well, I got nothing. I like this mostly so my filament doesn't get dusty when I cut stuff out with my Shapeoko.

comments.author: wellenreitr

comments.text: I haven't needed a back plate, so I haven't made one. I've got two dry boxes in rotation these days, and I haven't had any of the rod holders pull out from the plastic containers using typical 3mm hardware. I'm printing with makergeeks filament, and their spools are on the wide end of the spectrum. So, I've got 3 spools per box, and there hasn't been much of an issue. I've seen some other remixes and such where people are holding something like 6-8 spools using PVC, and they look to be fine too.

comments.text: I'm a "dry box believer" maybe because ambient humidity in my home can run 50%+ sometimes, but I definitely notice a difference in filament performance between the day it comes out of the shipper's bag and a week or two later.  I can get it back "like new" by baking the filament in the oven at 180F for 2 hours, but that's a pain compared to a dry box.

I have been developing this Quad-copter for several months now. I have done extensive testing on the frame and finally got it to the point of publishing it. The main spars of the H frame are made from anodized aluminum drinking straws. They can sometimes be purchased at convenience stores for drinking your favorite frozen drink. I have put together a very easy to print craft that is very rigid and very easy to fly. I know it is not 100% printed but the addition of the aluminum made a huge difference in flight, stability, and looks. In addition the parts are all pretty small.

Video
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aNkaYDd_NBo

The anti-vibration layer that is suspended in the center of the frame rails supports flight controller with vibration reduction in the dead center of the frame.

First revision was designed to hold a NAZA M Lite flight controller. It flew excellent. I actually gave that one to a friend and it is still flying today. The current version I added an Eagle Tree Vector. With the Vector I can have GPS and all out OSD. I really love the Vector. I have not tried this with a board style Flight Controller but I am sure you can adapt one.

I machined the aluminum straws on my CNC mill using a setup fixture to be sure the cross holes for the clamping bolts were all on the same plane.

You can purchase the straws already machined by me here
http://www.ebay.com/itm/-/291535733858

My latest addition was the tilt camera system on the front. This system allows the cameras to look up when doing high speed flights and to tilt way down for landing approach. I fly FPV and tried to incorporate all my wishes into this machine.

Payload testing yielded the ASQ with a 4000mAh battery had no problem flying a full 12oz can of soda around the yard. Still had plenty of lift.

Speed testing provided me with a very impresive 55MPH
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FhCpxSUDKE8

I fly 8X5 HQ Bullnose Props that I purchase from
http://www.readymaderc.com

The Q-Brain 20A 4 in 1 speed controller works great in this frame. I am sure you can fit whatever speed controller you want into it but that is what it is designed to hold.

The motors are EMAX MT2216 810KV purchased from
http://www.stoneblueairlines.com

I also purchased my radio gear and my Eagle Tree Vector from
http://www.stoneblueairlines.com
These guys are really good to work with!

Please feel free to make modifications to this design. Lets work together and make something sweet. If anyone is interested I can add the Solidworks files. I have attached a .pdf of my build sheet. It is a reverse take down of the assembly. It has all the parts for the base frame build on the BOM.

Motor mounts and end tube clamps must be strong so I used 90% fill. Most of the other parts can be less fill but I would not go below 50%.
My model is made from ABS

Use the PDF as a guide to assemble once you have the parts.

description.text:
hollow ping pong ball, with a uniform thickness (0.8mm, or twice my extrusion width - can be changed in the .scad file).

about twice as heavy by default as an official ping pong ball, so actually more usable perhaps outdoors.

when combined with an actual (concrete) ping pong table, it held up for a few minutes (after taking quite a test beating earlier).

-I wanted to have a supportless hollow on the inside, and I found that Cura has a nice option for this ("touching buildplate only" support)

-support angle needed to be about 35 for me, or the bottom part would start to curl during printing

-EXTWIDTH in .scad file should be equal to your extrusion width. the outside will be twice as thick. I haven't tried going thinner, so no idea what will happen.

-I only tested this with polymax filament, which is a fantastic PLA filament. slightly disappointed that the 0.8mm ball only held up for a few minutes though, or I would have tried to make it thinner (perhaps it's because I beat the hell out of it as a test before actually playing.. :-))

-a regular ping pong ball weighs about 2.7 grams. the 0.8mm version printed with polymax weights about 5.6 grams. so we'd have to go to about 0.5mm to come close.. but that doesn't sound very strong. perhaps epoxy glue on the inside might help..?

-my settings: 0.1mm layer height, 240 degrees, 60 degrees bed. perhaps 0.1mm is not optimal for strength..

-polish to grit 320, which takes about half an hour to do nicely manually, but it's hard to see/feel the difference with an official ball after that.

-I still hope to try slic3r's 3d-hex infill at some point, just because it's so nice.

CHALLENGE:

can you make a stronger and/or lighter ping pong ball that is actually usable for a long time??

comments.text: Interesting! The picture indeed looks like a real ping pong ball. Question about scad file: why are you subtracting a very thin cylinder?
comments.author: Amplivibe

comments.text: thanks! it also feels and behaves like a real ball, though you can clearly feel it's heavier.. the cylinder is to avoid openscad concluding the ball is a solid.

author: esulat

title: Makergear M2 Shock System
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A shock system for the Makergear M2 printer.

Purpose - To help reduce vibration marks that can appear on the surface of a model when there is a lot of detail on the OD.

Added Bonus. - The table I have my printer on barely moves at all when printing.

Looks funny printing but helps.

You will need:
4 small rubber bands.
14 springs 3/8" Diam aprox 3/8-1/2" long 4-5 pound load.
(I used Smalley CS037-L4-S17 wave springs.
2 Leg assebblies
1 Side Assembly.

Print all parts . I used 2 walls and 15% infill .25 layer.

Take a top and a bottom leg and put together with the rubber-band.
Slip 3 of the springs in to the middle and there you have a assembly to put under one of the feet on the same side of the machine as the electronics enclosure .

Using the side top and bottom and assemble in the same way.

This assembly is designed to go under the z axis support clamp
that is under the machine.

Notes:
There are more springs on the side assembly as that side of the machine supports more weight.

Actually there should be 2 more springs than I used under the z-axis as I forgot to figure in for the filament hanging on the side of the machine.

You could use as is which still works quite well or you can use heavier springs or you can build up 2 more leg assemblies with lighter springs and add them in.

Enjoy.

Design files are included.

comments.text: I wonder how these springs reduce defects on the print. Shouldnt the printer produce the best prints when the frame is not moving at all?
comments.author: Kulturfolger

comments.text: The relationship between the frame and the table is un affected so print accuracy is unchanged. The intent is to absorb some of the micro vibrations that transfer to the frame and then back to the table. Doesn't get them all but it helps some. See picture of License Plate holder.
comments.author: Kulturfolger

description.text: LA HOMIES
Servo adapter to fit 40mm servo into big hole for InMoov elbow part. It is designed specifically for elbow but could be used for other parts.
Print it 0.2, no support is needed.
This thing isn't quite ready for download, I'm posting for suggestions.

UPDATE
**So I finally got around to more tweaking, Swapped out the power supply for an up-cycled ATX power supply. Hooked up the power switch, voltage and current meters and re-did the wiring completely which neatened things up a little.
hope you guys enjoy :)

UPDATE
I've modified the swivel feet to allow the printrbot to tilt onto its side. no more need to awkwardly balance the printer upside down in order to get to the board.

Have a look at my project page here:
https://hackaday.io/project/7083-printrbot-simple-metal-bed-upgrade

I had the new printbed cut from 3mm and 4mm Aluminium and tapped the holes in the 3mm frame to make things easier.

The new print volume is 270mm × 205mm × 140mm

the A3 sized .pdf files are also uploaded.

as for the parts to be printed, i mostly printed with 0.2mm layers and 15% infill, 20% for some structural parts. I'm still updating as i go along, the parts here already have some of the errors fixed.

Enjoy

0.2mm layer
3×layers all round
15%~25% infill
4mm brim

**For the thin walled Power supply end caps, be sure to print with
0.3mm 2× layers all round and 10% infill. In my case I also needed to set down the flowrate to 85%

I use masking tape to stick the brim to the printbed when printing long parts and i use toothpicks with hot glue to prop tall prints against falling over on at least three sides.

title: Star Wars X-wing: Death Star turret

description.text:
My version of the Imperial turret found on the Death Star. I used an old Star Wars fan magazine to get the proportions and scale of the turret correct.

This is part of a ground based Imperial outpost I created.

All the pieces can be made with no support. The guns should be printed with the barrel pointing up. After printing they should be glued in place on the turret. The turret itself is snug enough to stay in place and not need glue.

This file is a free download. Please note that it is listed as “non-commercial”. Neither you nor I are allowed to buy or sell physical copies of this 3D model. You are allowed (and encouraged) to print copies for your own personal use. If you have been re-directed to this file from a source other than my site on thingiverse.com they have done so without my permission. Thank you for respecting the rights of the original copyright holder.

title: Star Wars X-wing: Imperial infantry bunker

description.text:
The Episode VII trailer #2 shows X-wings flying over a lake on some unknown planet. This inspired me to create a 'trench run' style scenario game for X-wing except this time it was on the surface of a planet.
This bunker is a place for imperial stormtroopers to hang out while repelling ground assaults by the rebel scum. You can use these as scenery for a ground level game or as part of a scenario. I'm using epic scale space marines as stand-ins because I don't have any 6mm stormtroopers.

This file is a free download. Since it is listed as 'creative commons - attribution' there are very few restrictions on how you use these files. The Episode VII trailer #2 shows X-wings flying over a lake on some unknown planet. This inspired me to create a 'trench run' style scenario game for X-wing except this time it was on the surface of a planet.

This can be used as general scenery or as part of a scenario game. When I use this in my scenario it will be right next to a lake with the coolant tunnel (the right side of the building) on the water.

Your target is this reactor. On the right side of the building there's a small thermal exhaust port, right below the main port. The shaft leads directly to the reactor system. A precise hit will start a chain reaction which should destroy the entire Imperial outpost. It's ray shielded, so you will have to use proton torpedoes...
The Force will be with you.

The Episode VII trailer #2 shows that X-wings can fly in atmosphere, not just in space. This inspired me to create a 'trench run' style scenario game for X-wing except this time on the surface of a planet.

Another part of the Imperial base, a landing pad for shuttle craft, TIE fighters, or visiting bounty hunters. There's a hole in the center so the Lambda shuttle will sit centered on the pad. You can use this as scenery for a "ground level" game or as part of a scenario mission.

This file is a free download. Since it is listed as 'creative commons - attribution' there are very few restrictions on how you use these files. You are welcome (and encouraged) to print them out for yourself for personal use. You are also allowed to buy and sell physical copies of the models. However, if you use my files and my pictures you should provide a link back to where you got them. Thanks.

The Episode VII trailer #2 shows X-wings flying over a lake on some unknown planet. This inspired me to create a 'trench run' style scenario game for X-wing except this time it was on the surface of a planet.

Based off of the stormtrooper transport my friend had when I was a little kid. Six troopers sit upright in little tubes on the sides of the vehicle, looking very uncomfortable and vulnerable to Rebel fire. Still, useful for moving your troopers from building to building.
This doesn't have any practical purpose in the miniatures game, it's just background scenery to make the the Imperial outpost look inhabited.

This file is a free download. Since it is listed as 'creative commons - attribution' there are very few restrictions on how you use these files. title: Star Wars X-wing: Imperial storage tanks

description.text:
News flash (to me anyway), X-wing fighters can fly at ground level, not just in space. Based on the latest Ep VII movie trailer I made a 'trench run' style scenario to play with my friends, which meant they needed a ground based Imperial outpost to blow up.

Not sure what's in these storage tanks but it's probably something important based on the number of defense turrets surrounding them. You can use these as basic scenery for a ground level game or as part of a scenario.

This file is a free download. Since it is listed as 'creative commons - attribution' there are very few restrictions on how you use these files. You are welcome (and encouraged) to print them out for yourself for personal use. You are also allowed to buy and sell physical copies of the models. title: Adjustable Seidenstrasse Rohrpost Capsule
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Adjustable Seidenstrasse Rohrpost Capsule
--

I made an adjustable Rohrpost-Capsule for the CCC-Camp 2015 and upcoming CCC-Congresses for use with the Seidenstrasse-RohrpostSystem.

The Capsule is adjustable within the scad-file, but not fully parametric due to lack of time remaining to the Camp.

Main Features of this Capsule are:

  • Thiner middle area for better movment in tight curves.
  • Integrated and adjustable holes for LED-stripes and cableties to secure them.
  • the "bulky" area on both sides sould be the right size to add velcro on the outside.
  • sliding rails with an endstop to the bottom to insertplates out of plastic, wood or metal, e.G. to mount your favourite electronics to it (the "default" adruino-pcb-width matches exactly between the rails, even thou this is archieved by accident [uno,leonardo, ethernet duemilanove and mega 2560 are fitting in definitely, even 2 boards at the same time] the Rails have been originally desinged to house a raspberry PI, but there was not enought space in the middle of the capsule)
  • screwable design

The STLs I provide have slightly more than 200mm (long version) and 160mm (small version), but you can adjust them for your needs. Remixes are very welcome.

For more Information of the Seidenstrasse-System visit https://events.ccc.de/camp/2015/wiki/Village:Seidenstrasse

See you at the Camp!

edit: overall weight including LEDs is about 150 gramms.

important VARS in the scad:

h_overall=200; //overall height of the capsule including top, for some reason the final capsule gets slightly higher (5mm or so)
mt=3; // thickness of the Material, especially the walls
led_pos_t=0; // 3 predefined positions for led-stripes, set to "1" where you want to have some
cable_holes=1; // 1=yes, 0=no, Holes for cables, does only apply when ledpos$N is set
ziptie_holes=1; // 1=yes, 0=no, Holes for zipties, does only apply when ledpos$N is set
insert=1; //1=yes, 0=no, 2 pairs of sliding rails with an offset from the center.

Cam-Hole-Vars for the Top are already in the SCAD, but not yet implemented, feel free to do this.

I had a 0.35-Nozzle attached to my Printer, so estimated Printing time was about 24 hours, but with a .5 nozzle this would be far less. Prints well on delta-printers ;-)

The most famous landmark of Greece's Naxos Island is the Portara, a massive 2,500-year-old marble doorway that leads nowhere!
The Portara stands on Palatia, which was once a hill but is now a separate little island connected to Naxos by a causeway. (The Mediterranean has risen significantly since ancient times.)

The Portara is the entrance to an unfinished temple that faces directly toward Delos, Apollo's birthplace. For this reason most scholars believe it was dedicated to Apollo, but some think it was built in honor of Dionysus, who was worshipped on Naxos Island.

author: DomoticX

description.text:
See the World!

This Challenge charged us makers to create something iconic -- a place or famous thing on this planet. The thing I decided to model for the Challenge is not just a famous place to see in the world. While it is a world-famous landmark, It is also a monument to those that went into the unknown to #SeeTheWorld. The people of the United States of America have always been among the forefront of those seeking to see new parts of this world. From our very pilgrimage to North America to Lewis and Clark's adventure, we have run full-speed into the unknown. From Alaska to the Moon, Americans have always been curious people.

The Gateway Arch in St. Louis, Missouri was built from 1963-1966 to specifically honor Lewis and Clark's expedition into the American west during the years of 1803 and 1804 and America's Westward expansion. At 630 feet, it is the tallest monument in the entire United States.

Design

The Arch's architect, Eero Saarinen, used very strict mathematics to describe the shape of his Arch. The use of these equations made it possible to make an exact 3D model using SolidWorks.

Centroid Curve:

The centroid curve is a line that passes through an imaginary point along the Arch's cross-section. This curve is considered a form of a catenary curve, and is governed by the following equation:
y = 693.8597 - 68.7672cosh(0.0100333x)
Where Y is height about the ground, and X is distance from the center of the arch. Because SolidWorks does not support the hyperbolic cosine function, I converted that equation into a function of e^(x) using the definition of the hyperbolic cosine. The new equation became:
y = 693.8597 - 34.3836(e^(0.0100333x)+e^(-0.0100333x))
Graphing this from -299.2239 to +299.2239 gave an accurate model of the centroid curve.

Cross-Section

Because the Arch's cross-section is not constant throughout, another function is used to calculate the area of any particular cross-section. (A cross-section being defined as a plane perpendicular to the centroid curve at any point):
Q = 125.1406cosh(0.010333x)
Where Q is cross-sectional area. Because all cross-sections are equilateral triangles, I then derived the equation for an equilateral triangle's base length as a function of its area:
B = (2*3^(3/4)*sqrt(Q)) / 3
Where B is the base length. I then combined these two equations to create an equation for the base length of a cross section as a function of its distance from the center of the arch:
B = (2*3^(3/4)*sqrt(125.1406cosh(0.010333x))) / 3
(Yeah, I know that's a mess, but it works).

Modeling

I then added a number of points, at measured distances from the center, on the centroid curve that I had already graphed in SolidWorks. I created planes perpendicular to the centroid that contained these points. I then made sketches on these planes of each cross-section, using the dimensions calculated from the equations above. After creating about a dozen and a half of these cross-sections, I used a loft feature to create the solid shape of the arch.

3D Print-ability

In order to make the arch 3D printable, I had to split it into several separate sections, interconnected with pins. I used AutoDesk MeshMixer to scale and rotate the sections so that a flat side would always be facing the print bed. I also designed a base so it would be able to stand on its own.

The Middle Two Sections

Because I wanted to model the Arch in a high level of detail, but also wanted to be able to fit it in a sane amount of space, I had to come to a compromise -- I would model the solid shape of the entire arch at 1:1200 scale, then model the middle two sections at 1:120 scale. I also created a base for these two sections so that they make a classy display on their own.

Conclusion

The Gateway Arch stands as a masterpiece of mathematical architecture, beautiful as both art and math. It was a technologically unprecedented project that was engineered and built flawlessly. Today it stands as a monument to those who dared to #SeeTheWorld.

Credits

All the information I used in designing the Arch is available from various sources online, including but not limited to; The National Park Service, The University of Houston, The Mathematical Sciences Research Institute, and Wikipedia. Send me a personal message if you want any of the specific URLs I consulted.

Main Arch

Print two each of the files bottom.stl, top.stl, and ArchBase.stl. The arch sections require a raft, but otherwise print without support material, although a small amount may help the quality of top.stl. Print one copy of pins.stl. I printed these parts at a layer height of 0.1mm. Glue of your choice is recommended when assembling the pieces.

Middle Sections

The middle sections print pretty easily. Just print them upright without support material. The base is equally straight-forward. I again used 0.1mm layer height.

my tribute to this monumental game, we all belive in.
Big thanks to ID-Software
printed in 0.4 PLA

title: E3D V6 Clone Cooling 40mm Fan Duct

description.text: Its E3D V6 Clone fan duct that will clip over the the cooling fins. It is for the Sunhokey Prusa i3 2015 printer. The original E3D fan ducts on thingiverse have a slightly smaller diameter for the cooling fins and as a result don't fit (find are ~25mm in diameter). Also seems to allow more flow than the previous one a downloaded as the air flow is less constricted in this model as these fans don't really make any pressure.

Printed fan side down to the bed to reduce support material with 15% infill strong and like no issues with breaking when installing on or removing. Use 3x16 mm nuts and bolts, model has nut cut outs for ease of installation.

title: Fully 3D Printable RC Vehicle (Improved from previously posted)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The vehicle I have designed was inspired by the OPENRC Project. I wanted to make it, but I wanted much more simplicity in the mechanics. I had a few DJI phantom brushless motors and various other aerial RC hardware laying around. I decided to go with these parts because I have never seen it done before.

Drivetrain:
The motors are built into the rear wheels, Eliminating Shafts, gearing, belts, and other costly linkages. The Result is a crazy fast, relatively high torque vehicle. (I am afraid to go full throttle as I have a relatively small place to drive my rc car.)
The ESCs( Motor Controllers) should be identical. I used different ones (one that is Simon K and one that isn't) and I got more torque from the non-Simon K ESC.

Steering and Front End:
The steering uses two 9g servos that simply are part of the Top A-arm. When the servo is able to move with the suspension, it eliminates the need for a complicated linkage system.

Wheels:
I should say, all of the wheels that you will need for this vehicle will need to be custom made. I designed and printed a road set and an off-road set. I doubt the wheels I used will fit anybody's tires. I tried to make the wheel versatility as easy to adapt as possible. For the Front wheels, a skateboard bearing was used for the wheel to freely rotate around. The rear wheels use the motor of your choice, therefore, the inner wheel diameter will differ with whatever motor is being used.

The Printed parts:
I recommend using a high density infill when printing your version(if you decide to do so). I used 20% infill with PLA and a crash destroyed every part in early development.
I used PLA for every printed part of the car, however, I wanted to use ABS, but I just cannot keep ABS on my heated bed.

Any transmitter should be suitable, just make sure that your servos are correctly mixed together to move in sync.

Building:
I included Screenshots as well as the assembly files from my CAD software to help on the assembly process. If there are any questions regarding assembly, feel free to leave a comment and I will do my best to help you.

ENJOY!

https://youtu.be/yQFBOyBylDg
I included Assembly files as well as Screenshots of the assembly.

10/30/2017 - new pics. Added some Bondo filler to clean up the print lines, then painted in rose gold and metallic.

I thought this would be fun, and just in time for halloween...for once - I've been wanting to make one of these for a while and just couldn't get around to it. This is my version of a horror classic from the movie 'Nightmare on Elm Street' - Freddie's "Glove"... or at least the fingers and hand plate. I created one finger (the pinky for my hand) and the hand plate and the rest is all about scaling. The files named with "other_" are the 'pinky' finger scaled up to 1.15 percent.

I have a small hand (I'm 5'5" and some change) so I created the pinky, checked the fit and through a little trial and error found a good scale for the rest of the fingers on my hand (1.15%). You may want to do the same unless you have some insight into finger ratios n such.

I used brass paper fasteners I got from JoAnne Fabrics for the "rivets" on the hand, and PLA "rivets" for the finger joints. ( A hot soldering iron makes this easy.)

For the glove I used the first cheap thing I could find in the garage. (Not being terribly picky about that part just now)

As mentioned in the description... figure out the size for your pinky (I know that sounds crappy) and scale the "other" files based on that. The uploaded "other" files are scaled to 1.15% versus the pinky.

Print 1 hand plate and 1 pinky of your size and 3 "other_" parts (finger tip, blade and knuckle) scaled based on any adjusted scaling you do to the pinky and hand plate. The blades have tabs for the finger tips, so they have to be in scale with each other) . If you find you need larger " everything" then remember the hand plate is somewhat proportionate to the "pinky" and may require scaling as well.

Assemble the parts by attaching the finger tips to the knuckle parts for each finger. I used 3mm PLA rivets and a soldering iron. Then attach the completed fingers to the hand plate and a glove of your choosing using brass paper fasteners or any thing else you think will look good.

The blades tab into the fingers and can be glued or not ( they fit well without and are probably safer that way).

title: Yet Another Prusa Mendel Z Coupling

description.text: Couples a 5mm motor shaft to an 8mm threaded rod, ensuring they are coaxial, but allowing some angular movement if the rod is not straight. See http://hydraraptor.blogspot.com/2011/06/yet-another-prusa-z-coupling.html.
Place some plastic tubing over the motor shaft and then clamp it with M3x20 bolts. Make sure there is no grease on the motor shaft by wiping with alcohol.

Quick printing, single-use rocket fins attaches directly to Type C model rocket motor.
This piece is a single-wall print (0.4mm nozzle) and therefore prints very quickly but is fragile. If it survives landing it's reusable...but don' count on it.
It fits tightly over the bottom of a Type B model rocket engine (no adhesive or tape required) and has a slot for the launcher rod.
The dowloade includes g-code, stl, and SketchUp files, feel free to edit/remix, but read the instructions for advice and to save yourself headaches! It's a very finicky print!

This model is intended to be printed with a 0.4mm nozzle and 0.2mm layers, Changing these settings can easily cause problems with the print as the entire print has only a single wall.
If editing/remixing be careful to keep the fins oriented on only X or only y axis, as you can easily end up with problems if they're on an angle (that's why I made 4 fins instead of 3).

title: car air vent mount for Iphone 6 plus

description.text:
This is a mount for my son's phone that hooks onto the air vent grill and has a support to the top of the dash board.

It also works with my daughter's iphone 6 plus on her air vent. She chose not to use the optional top support. see double photo

The holder can support a phone up to 88 mm wide and 15 mm thick including the case. It will grip about 90 mm of the phone. The iphone 6 plus is about 158 mm long.

The last two figures provide front and back dimensions. It is recommended that you verify that your phone fits in the holder and that the holder fits in your vent grill.

For the optional dash board support you will also need two bolts and two lock nuts
two 3mm diameter by 20 mm long bolts
or two 1/8" diameter by 7/8" long bolts
and corresponding lock nuts
30 mm (1.25") piece of double sided foam tape or equivalent

print the files:
dash_mount_150718_base.stl
dash_mount_150719_other.stl

pictures:
part_letters.png identifies each of the printed parts with a letter
assembled_view_1a.png identifies which parts are attached to the top of the base
assembled_view_2a.png identifies which parts are attached to the bottom of the base

drill out the holes in the brackets (D) and the link (E) with a 3 mm (or 1/8") drill bit

glue(with acetone) parts A through C to the base

for the optional dash board support glue one part D to the base.
when dry secure link to both part D brackets using the bolts and lock nuts. Do not overtighten, there is an intentional gap to allow the link to swing freely.

to install:

insert the hooks (parts C) into the air vent. check to make sure it won't slip out.

attach the optional link support bracket (D) to top of the dashboard using the double sided foam tape

test the mount to verify:

  1. it does not slip out of the air vent
  2. if you did not install the top mount link, verify that it does not flop away from the dashboard

Welcome to the Falkirk Wheel in Scotland; the only rotating boat lift in the world. It features Celtic-inspired, double-headed axe arms, which hold two water-filled gondolas to carry boats. It took 8 years to plan, design, and construct between 1994 and 2002. The Falkirk Wheel connects the Forth and Clyde Canal with the Union Canal for the first time since the 1930's when 11 navigation locks were removed.

Hundreds of thousands of people visit the Falkirk Wheel each year and now you can enjoy my approximate 1/500 scale model from your 3D printer.

Design:
Using Blender alongside photos of the wheel that I found online, I modeled a moveable assembly composed of 17 printable parts. I took care to ensure that all parts could be simply printed without supports and assembled without additional connecting hardware. All that is needed is a 3D printer and filament.

The rotating arms hold gondolas that maintain an upright position using gravity. The model is spun by hand by pushing on the arms, or twisting the knurled shaft stub that extends through the back support. This shaft has the ability to be modified for a gear reduced drive. A worm drive modification in the downloads contains replacement parts for adding a stepper motor.

https://youtu.be/LPEEhIc5AuE
https://youtu.be/aYavmDMNJbg

No supports needed
Print scale 100% of .stl model size.
See video for assembly guidance.

Settings for my printer and filament:
PLA, 180°C
Infill 10%
Layer height 0.2mm

Part list:
-Wheel front arm + shaft.
-Wheel rear arm.
-Gondolas (x2)
-Wheel base.
-Wheel's front support.
-Wheel's rear support.
-Central gear.
-Aquaduct.
-Aquaduct supports (x4)
-Aquaduct base.
-Water inserts.

description.text:
I made this device for my dad's walker - he suffers from Parkinson's disease. People that have this some times "freeze" and have to count to get themselves to move again. The idea is that the device shines a laser line on the ground where the person walks through. For some reason they focus on the light and freeze less. The upgrade to a walker is really expensive so i bought a laser level from Amazon and pulled the parts off to repurpose. (Link below) The laser component is really just a pointer, and it runs through a prism. While testing, i made the discovery that the prism that came with the laser level has to be offset to create the laser "line" that shines at the floor while the box is attached to the walker. I plan on using some cat5 scrap cable to link the switch box (attached with zip ties) on the handle to the main box that attaches to the tube on the bracket below.

http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00PQ4PJYC?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00

description.text:
This is a tablet stand made to looked like welded chain links. The links and link assembly were modeled with Solidworks. Then the file was modified in Rhino to union all the parts. Then it was modified in Meshmixer to smooth the link joints, add the the little studs on the front three links and add support structure. This print is challenging - Lots of steep overhangs and bridging. I'll admit it took a few attempts to get it to print. Usually the bottom of link loops broke away from the support posts.

author: discojon

description.text: a machine to slap people in the face over the internet - first prototype

Build as a university project together with u\Saiman, this is the device so many have been waiting for - a machine to slap people in the face over the internet. Building it is quite easy, just:
  • laser-cut the hand and base from your favorite sturdy material
  • if you have only thin material, cut all 4 gear and arm instances on your laser and glue them together to make them stable, if your material is thick enough only 1 layer is needed.
  • Either cut the springy mount for the slap hand from flexible material like cardboard, or 3D print the mount.
  • Mount hand on arm using the mount-spring
  • put a servo into the pre-cut rectangle in the base-plate and attach the big gear to the servo(we used screws).
  • glue a rod for the gear on the base (use the right distance so the gear can move easily, maybe use wooden blocks to get the right height) and fix the arm-gear on the rod, so that it can freely turn when moved by the gear on the servo.
  • connect the servo to your arduino flash the included processing file to the controller and run the 2nd processing file on your computer.
  • Push the BIG RED BUTTON.
  • !!!SLAP!!!
    • There is currently a client-server based software in development, based on python, that should allow the use of multiple of these devices over the internet. We'll add the files here(or to MK2), when they're ready. In the meantime: Feel free to improve the design and mechanics and add your comments below.

title: Mobius clean plate and vibration dampeners for Diatone FPV250 V2 quadcopter frame

description.text: I saw J0bro's design, but it didn't fit my frame, so I designed a new one which fit my dimensions. I also didn't feel like ordering the vibration dampeners so I designed those as well and printed them in NinjaFlex which seems to have worked. The video from the first flight can be seen at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YM12zOrDXgE and you can see very little jello despite propellers which aren't up to the job (I've got stiffer ones on order) and haven't been balanced. I sanded the raised part smooth and installed the clean plate with the thick side up towards the camera - this provides more clearance for the vibration dampeners between the plate and the camera. I used 3 small cable ties in both slots so the plate wouldn't slide back and forth. The clasp of the ties is underneath in the same space as the dampeners.

I printed the clean plate out of PLA with a fairly high infill 90%. I printed the vibration dampeners out of Ninjaflex with only 1 outside/top/bottom layer and 10% infill - it needed to be as squishy as possible. Even 2 layers made it too stiff and hard to install.
